starts with the - sign will be removed from the entire search order.
For example:

    exe_search_path /some/prepended/path
    exe_search_path +/some/appended/path
    exe_search_path -/some/excluded/path

multi_options.name: menu_map
multi_options.doc:
Specify entries for various menus in kitty. Currently only the global menubar on macOS
is supported. For example:

   menu_map global "Actions:Launch something special" launch --hold --type=os-window sh -c "echo hello world"

This will create a menu entry named "Launch something special" in an "Actions" menu in the macOS global menubar.
Sub-menus can be created by adding more levels separated by the :: characters.

multi_options.name: action_alias
multi_options.doc:
Define action aliases to avoid repeating the same options in multiple mappings.
Aliases can be defined for any action and will be expanded recursively. For
example, the above alias allows you to create mappings to launch a new tab in
the current working directory without duplication:

    map f1 launch_tab vim
    map f2 launch_tab emacs

Similarly, to alias kitten invocation:

    action_alias hints kitten hints --hints-offset=0

multi_options.name: kitten_alias
multi_options.doc:
Like action_alias above, but specifically for kittens. Generally, prefer
to use action_alias. This option is a legacy version, present for
backwards compatibility. It causes all invocations of the aliased kitten to be
substituted. So the example above will cause all invocations of the hints kitten
to have the --hints-offset=0
option applied.

actions.name: change_font_size
actions.short: Change the font size for the current or all OS Windows

actions.name: clear_last_command
actions.short: Clear the last command

actions.name: clear_screen
actions.short: Clear screen

actions.name: clear_scrollback
actions.short: Clear scrollback

actions.name: clear_selection
actions.short: Clear the current selection

actions.name: clear_terminal
actions.short: Clear the terminal
actions.doc:
For example:

    # Reset the terminal
    map f1 clear_terminal reset active
    # Clear the terminal screen by erasing all contents
    map f1 clear_terminal clear active
    # Clear the terminal scrollback by erasing it
    map f1 clear_terminal scrollback active
    # Scroll the contents of the screen into the scrollback
    map f1 clear_terminal scroll active
    # Clear everything on screen up to the line with the cursor or the start of the current prompt (needs shell integration)
    # Useful for clearing the screen up to the shell prompt and moving the shell prompt to the top of the screen.
    map f1 clear_terminal to_cursor active
    # Same as above except cleared lines are moved into scrollback
    map f1 clear_terminal to_cursor_scroll active
    # Erase the last command and its output (needs shell integration to work)
    map f1 clear_terminal last_command active

actions.name: clear_terminal_and_scrollback
actions.short: Clear to start

actions.name: close_os_window
actions.short: Close the currently active OS Window

actions.name: close_other_os_windows
actions.short: Close all other OS Windows other than the OS Window containing the currently active window

actions.name: close_other_tabs_in_os_window
actions.short: Close all the tabs in the current OS window other than the currently active tab

actions.name: close_other_windows_in_tab
actions.short: Close all windows in the tab other than the currently active window

actions.name: close_session
actions.short: Close a session, that is, close all windows that belong to the session.
actions.doc:
Examples:
    # Ask for the session to close
    map f1 close_session
    # Close the currently active session
    map f1 close_session .
    # Close session by name
    map f1 close_session "my session"
    # Close session by path to session file
    map f1 close_session "/path/to/session/file.kitty-session"

actions.name: close_shared_ssh_connections
actions.short: Close all shared SSH connections

actions.name: close_tab
actions.short: Close the current tab

actions.name: close_window
actions.short: Close the currently active window

actions.name: close_window_with_confirmation
actions.short: Close window with confirmation
actions.doc:
Asks for confirmation before closing the window. If you don't want the
confirmation when the window is sitting at a shell prompt
(requires shell_integration), use:

    map f1 close_window_with_confirmation ignore-shell

actions.name: combine
actions.short: Combine multiple actions and map to a single keypress
actions.doc:
The syntax is:

    map key combine action1 action2 action3 ...

For example:

    map kitty_mod+e combine : new_window : next_layout
    map kitty_mod+e combine | new_tab | goto_tab -1

actions.name: copy_and_clear_or_interrupt
actions.short: Copy the selected text from the active window to the clipboard and clear selection, if no selection, send SIGINT (aka ctrl+c)

actions.name: copy_ansi_to_clipboard
actions.short: Copy the selected text from the active window to the clipboard with ANSI formatting codes

actions.name: copy_last_command_output
actions.short: Copy the last non-empty output from a shell command to the clipboard
actions.doc: Requires shell_integration to work

actions.name: copy_or_interrupt
actions.short: Copy the selected text from the active window to the clipboard, if no selection, send SIGINT (aka ctrl+c)

actions.name: copy_or_noop
actions.short: Copy the selected text from the active window to the clipboard, if no selection, pass the key through to the application running in the terminal.

actions.name: copy_to_buffer
actions.short: Copy the selection from the active window to the specified buffer

actions.name: copy_to_clipboard
actions.short: Copy the selected text from the active window to the clipboard

actions.name: create_marker
actions.short: Create a new marker

actions.name: debug_config
actions.short: Show the effective configuration kitty is running with

actions.name: decrease_background_opacity
actions.short: Decrease background opacity

actions.name: decrease_font_size
actions.short: Decrease font size

actions.name: detach_tab
actions.short: Detach a tab, moving it to another OS Window
actions.doc: Detach the specified tabs and either move them into a new OS window or add them to the OS window containing the tab specified by kitten @ detach-tab --target-tab

actions.name: detach_window
actions.short: Detach a window, moving it to another tab or OS Window
actions.doc: Detach the specified windows and either move them into a new tab, a new OS window or add them to the specified tab. Use the special value new for kitten @ detach-window --target-tab to move to a new tab. If no target tab is specified the windows are moved to a new OS window.

actions.name: disable_ligatures_in
actions.short: Turn on/off ligatures in the specified window
actions.doc: Control ligature rendering for the specified windows/tabs (defaults to active window). The STRATEGY can be one of: never, always, cursor.

actions.name: discard_event
actions.short: Discard this event completely ignoring it

actions.name: dump_lines_with_attrs
actions.short: Show a dump of the current lines in the scrollback + screen with their line attributes

actions.name: edit_config_file
actions.short: Edit the kitty.conf config file in your favorite text editor

actions.name: eighth_window
actions.short: Focus the eighth window

actions.name: fifth_window
actions.short: Focus the fifth window

actions.name: first_window
actions.short: Focus the first window

actions.name: focus_visible_window
actions.short: Focus a visible window by pressing the number of the window. Window numbers are displayed
actions.doc: over the windows for easy selection in this mode. See visual_window_select_characters.

actions.name: fourth_window
actions.short: Focus the fourth window

actions.name: full_background_opacity
actions.short: Make background fully opaque

actions.name: goto_file_line
actions.short: Open the selected file at the selected line
actions.doc:
Select something that looks like filename:linenum and open it in
your default editor at the specified line number.

actions.name: goto_layout
actions.short: Switch to the named layout
actions.doc:
In case there are multiple layouts with the same name and different options,
specify the full layout definition or a unique prefix of the full definition.

For example:

    map f1 goto_layout tall
    map f2 goto_layout fat:bias=20

actions.name: goto_session
actions.short: Switch to the specified session, creating it if not already present

actions.name: goto_tab
actions.short: Go to the specified tab, by number, starting with 1
actions.doc:
Zero and negative numbers go to previously active tabs.
Use the select_tab action to interactively select a tab
to go to.

actions.name: grab_keyboard
actions.short: Grab the keyboard. This means global shortcuts defined in the OS will be passed to kitty instead. Useful if
actions.doc:
you want to create an OS modal window. How well this
works depends on the OS/window manager/desktop environment. On Wayland it works only if the compositor implements
the inhibit-keyboard-shortcuts protocol.
On macOS Apple doesn't allow applications to grab the keyboard without special permissions, so it doesn't work.

actions.name: hide_macos_app
actions.short: Hide macOS kitty application

actions.name: hide_macos_other_apps
actions.short: Hide macOS other applications

actions.name: increase_background_opacity
actions.short: Increase background opacity

actions.name: increase_font_size
actions.short: Increase font size

actions.name: input_unicode_character
actions.short: Input an arbitrary unicode character

actions.name: insert_chosen_directory
actions.short: Insert chosen directory
actions.doc:
Select a directory using the choose-files kitten and insert
it into the terminal.

actions.name: insert_chosen_file
actions.short: Insert chosen file
actions.doc:
Select a file using the choose-files kitten and insert
it into the terminal.

actions.name: insert_selected_hash
actions.short: Insert selected hash
actions.doc:
Select something that looks like a hash and insert it into the terminal. Useful
with git, which uses SHA1 hashes to identify commits.

actions.name: insert_selected_line
actions.short: Insert selected line
actions.doc:
Select a line of text and insert it into the terminal. Useful for the output of
things like: ls -1.

actions.name: insert_selected_path
actions.short: Insert selected path
actions.doc:
Select a path/filename and insert it into the terminal. Useful, for instance to
run git commands on a filename output from a previous git
command.

actions.name: insert_selected_word
actions.short: Insert selected word
actions.doc: Select words and insert into terminal.

actions.name: kitten
actions.short: Run the specified kitten

actions.name: kitty_shell
actions.short: Run the kitty shell to control kitty with commands

actions.name: last_used_layout
actions.short: Go to the previously used layout

actions.name: launch
actions.short: Launch the specified program in a new window/tab/etc.
actions.doc:
Flags:
  --source-window
    A match expression to select the window from which data such as title, colors, env vars, screen contents, etc.
  --window-title, --title
    The title to set for the new window.
  --tab-title
    The title for the new tab if launching in a new tab.
  --type=window|tab|os-window|os-panel|overlay|overlay-main|background|clipboard|primary
    Where to launch the child process: (default: window)
  --keep-focus, --dont-take-focus
    Keep the focus on the currently active window instead of switching to the newly opened window.
  --cwd
    The working directory for the newly launched child.
  --add-to-session
    Add the newly created window/tab to the specified session.
  --env (repeatable)
    Environment variables to set in the child process.
  --var (repeatable)
    User variables to set in the created window.
  --hold
    Keep the window open even after the command being executed exits, at a shell prompt.
  --copy-colors
    Set the colors of the newly created window to be the same as the colors in the source window.
  --copy-cmdline
    Ignore any specified command line and instead use the command line from the source window.
  --copy-env
    Copy the environment variables from the source window into the newly launched child process.
  --location=first|after|before|neighbor|last|vsplit|hsplit|split|default
    Where to place the newly created window when it is added to a tab which already has existing windows in it. (default: default)
  --next-to
    A match expression to select the window next to which the new window is created.
  --bias
    The bias used to alter the size of the window. (default: 0)
  --allow-remote-control
    Programs running in this window can control kitty (even if remote control is not enabled in kitty.conf). Note that any program with the right level of permissions can still write to the pipes of any other program on the same computer and therefore can control kitty. It can, however, be useful to block programs running on other computers (for example, over SSH) or as other users. See --remote-control-password for ways to restrict actions allowed by remote control.
  --remote-control-password (repeatable)
    Restrict the actions remote control is allowed to take.
  --stdin-source=none|@selection|@screen|@screen_scrollback|@alternate|@alternate_scrollback|@first_cmd_output_on_screen|@last_cmd_output|@last_visited_cmd_output
    Pass the screen contents as STDIN to the child process. (default: none)
  --stdin-add-formatting
    When using --stdin-source add formatting escape codes, without this only plain text will be sent.
  --stdin-add-line-wrap-markers
    When using --stdin-source add a carriage return at every line wrap location (where long lines are wrapped at screen edges).
  --marker
    Create a marker that highlights text in the newly created window.
  --os-window-class
    Set the WM_CLASS property on X11 and the application id property on Wayland for the newly created OS window when using --type=os-window.
  --os-window-name
    Set the WM_NAME property on X11 for the newly created OS Window when using --type=os-window.
  --os-window-title
    Set the title for the newly created OS window.
  --os-window-state=normal|fullscreen|maximized|minimized
    The initial state for the newly created OS Window. (default: normal)
  --logo
    Path to a PNG image to use as the logo for the newly created window.
  --logo-position
    The position for the window logo. Only takes effect if --logo is specified. See window_logo_position.
  --logo-alpha
    The amount the window logo should be faded into the background. (default: -1)
  --color (repeatable)
    Change colors in the newly launched window.
  --spacing (repeatable)
    Set the margin and padding for the newly created window.
  --watcher, -w (repeatable)
    Path to a Python file.
  --os-panel (repeatable)
    Options to control the creation of desktop panels.
  --hold-after-ssh
    When using --cwd=current or similar from a window that is running the ssh kitten, the new window will run a local shell after disconnecting from the remote host, when this option is specified.

actions.name: layout_action
actions.short: Perform a layout specific action

actions.name: load_config_file
actions.short: Reload the config file
actions.doc:
If mapped without arguments reloads the default config file, otherwise loads
the specified config files, in order. Loading a config file *replaces* all
config options. For example:

    map f5 load_config_file /path/to/some/kitty.conf

actions.name: macos_cycle_through_os_windows
actions.short: Cycle through OS windows on macOS

actions.name: macos_cycle_through_os_windows_backwards
actions.short: Cycle through OS windows backwards on macOS

actions.name: minimize_macos_window
actions.short: Minimize macOS window

actions.name: mouse_click_url
actions.short: Click the URL under the mouse

actions.name: mouse_click_url_or_select
actions.short: Click the URL under the mouse only if the screen has no selection

actions.name: mouse_handle_click
actions.short: Handle a mouse click
actions.doc:
Try to perform the specified actions one after the other till one of them is successful.
Supported actions are:

    selection - check for a selection and if one exists abort processing
    link - if a link exists under the mouse, click it
    prompt - if the mouse click happens at a shell prompt move the cursor to the mouse location

For examples, see conf-kitty-mouse.mousemap

actions.name: mouse_select_command_output
actions.short: Select clicked command output
actions.doc: Requires shell_integration to work

actions.name: mouse_selection
actions.short: Manipulate the selection based on the current mouse position
actions.doc: For examples, see conf-kitty-mouse.mousemap

actions.name: mouse_show_command_output
actions.short: Show clicked command output in a pager like less
actions.doc: Requires shell_integration to work

actions.name: move_tab_backward
actions.short: Move the active tab backward

actions.name: move_tab_forward
actions.short: Move the active tab forward

actions.name: move_window
actions.short: Move the window in the specified direction
actions.doc:
For example:

    map ctrl+left move_window left
    map ctrl+down move_window bottom

actions.name: move_window_backward
actions.short: Move active window backward (swap it with the previous window)

actions.name: move_window_forward
actions.short: Move active window forward (swap it with the next window)

actions.name: move_window_to_top
actions.short: Move active window to the top (make it the first window)

actions.name: neighboring_window
actions.short: Focus the neighboring window in the current tab
actions.doc:
For example:

    map ctrl+left neighboring_window left
    map ctrl+down neighboring_window bottom

actions.name: new_os_window
actions.short: New OS Window

actions.name: new_os_window_with_cwd
actions.short: New OS Window with the same working directory as the currently active window.
actions.doc: The new OS Window is added to the currently active session, if any.

actions.name: new_tab
actions.short: Create a new tab

actions.name: new_tab_with_cwd
actions.short: Create a new tab with working directory for the window in it set to the same as the active window.
actions.doc: The tab is added to the currently active session, if any.

actions.name: new_window
actions.short: Create a new window

actions.name: new_window_with_cwd
actions.short: Create a new window with working directory same as that of the active window.
actions.doc: The new window will belong to the active session if any.

actions.name: next_layout
actions.short: Go to the next enabled layout. Can optionally supply an integer to jump by the specified number.

actions.name: next_tab
actions.short: Make the next tab active

actions.name: next_window
actions.short: Focus the next window in the current tab

actions.name: ninth_window
actions.short: Focus the ninth window

actions.name: no_op
actions.short: Unbind a shortcut
actions.doc: Mapping a shortcut to no_op causes kitty to not intercept the key stroke anymore, instead passing it to the program running inside it.

actions.name: nth_os_window
actions.short: Focus the nth OS window if positive or the previously active OS windows if negative. When the number is larger
actions.doc:
than the number of OS windows focus the last OS window. A value of zero will refocus the currently focused OS window,
this is useful if focus is not on any kitty OS window at all, however, it will only work if the window manager
allows applications to grab focus. For example:

    # focus the previously active kitty OS window
    map ctrl+p nth_os_window -1
    # focus the current kitty OS window (grab focus)
    map ctrl+0 nth_os_window 0
    # focus the first kitty OS window
    map ctrl+1 nth_os_window 1
    # focus the last kitty OS window
    map ctrl+1 nth_os_window 999

actions.name: nth_window
actions.short: Focus the nth window if positive or the previously active windows if negative. When the number is larger
actions.doc:
than the number of windows focus the last window. For example:

    # focus the previously active window
    map ctrl+p nth_window -1
    # focus the first window
    map ctrl+1 nth_window 0

actions.name: open_kitty_website
actions.short: Open kitty Website

actions.name: open_selected_hyperlink
actions.short: Open the selected hyperlink
actions.doc:
Select a hyperlink (i.e. a URL that has been marked as such
by the terminal program, for example, by ls --hyperlink=auto).

actions.name: open_selected_path
actions.short: Open selected path
actions.doc: Select a path/filename and open it with the default open program.

actions.name: open_url
actions.short: Open the specified URL

actions.name: open_url_with_hints
actions.short: Click a URL using the keyboard

actions.name: pass_selection_to_program
actions.short: Pass the selected text from the active window to the specified program

actions.name: paste
actions.short: Paste the specified text into the current window. ANSI C escapes are decoded.

actions.name: paste_from_buffer
actions.short: Paste from the specified buffer to the active window

actions.name: paste_from_clipboard
actions.short: Paste from the clipboard to the active window

actions.name: paste_from_selection
actions.short: Paste from the primary selection, if present, otherwise the clipboard to the active window

actions.name: paste_selection
actions.short: Paste the current primary selection

actions.name: paste_selection_or_clipboard
actions.short: Paste the current primary selection or the clipboard if no selection is present

actions.name: pop_keyboard_mode
actions.short: End the current keyboard mode switching to the previous mode.

actions.name: previous_tab
actions.short: Make the previous tab active

actions.name: previous_window
actions.short: Focus the previous window in the current tab

actions.name: push_keyboard_mode
actions.short: Switch to the specified keyboard mode, pushing it onto the stack of keyboard modes.

actions.name: quit
actions.short: Quit, closing all windows

actions.name: reload_config_file
actions.short: Reload kitty.conf
actions.doc:
Reload kitty.conf, applying any changes since the last time it was
loaded. Note that a handful of options cannot be dynamically changed and
require a full restart of kitty. Particularly, when changing shortcuts for
actions located on the macOS global menu bar, a full restart is needed. You can
also map a keybinding to load a different config file, for example:

    map f5 load_config /path/to/alternative/kitty.conf

Note that all options from the original kitty.conf are discarded, in
other words the new configuration *replace* the old ones.

actions.name: remote_control
actions.short: Run a remote control command without needing to allow remote control
actions.doc:
For example:

    map f1 remote_control set-spacing margin=30

See rc_mapping for details.

actions.name: remote_control_script
actions.short: Run a remote control script without needing to allow remote control
actions.doc:
For example:

    map f1 remote_control_script /path/to/script arg1 arg2 ...

See rc_mapping for details.

actions.name: remove_marker
actions.short: Remove a previously created marker

actions.name: reset_background_opacity
actions.short: Reset background opacity

actions.name: reset_font_size
actions.short: Reset font size

actions.name: reset_terminal
actions.short: Reset the terminal
actions.doc:
You can create shortcuts to clear/reset the terminal. For example:

    # Reset the terminal
    map f1 clear_terminal reset active
    # Clear the terminal screen by erasing all contents
    map f1 clear_terminal clear active
    # Clear the terminal scrollback by erasing it
    map f1 clear_terminal scrollback active
    # Scroll the contents of the screen into the scrollback
    map f1 clear_terminal scroll active
    # Clear everything on screen up to the line with the cursor or the start of the current prompt (needs shell integration)
    map f1 clear_terminal to_cursor active
    # Same as above except cleared lines are moved into scrollback
    map f1 clear_terminal to_cursor_scroll active
    # Erase the last command and its output (needs shell integration to work)
    map f1 clear_terminal last_command active

If you want to operate on all kitty windows instead of just the current one, use
all instead of active.

Some useful functions that can be defined in the shell rc files to perform various kinds of
clearing of the current window:



    clear-only-screen() {
        printf "\e[H\e[2J"
    }

    clear-screen-and-scrollback() {
        printf "\e[H\e[3J"
    }

    clear-screen-saving-contents-in-scrollback() {
        printf "\e[H\e[22J"
    }

For instance, using these escape codes, it is possible to remap Ctrl+L
to both scroll the current screen contents into the scrollback buffer and clear
the screen, instead of just clearing the screen. For ZSH, in /.zshrc, add:



    ctrl_l() {
        builtin print -rn -- $'\r\e[0J\e[H\e[22J' >"$TTY"
        builtin zle .reset-prompt
        builtin zle -R
    }
    zle -N ctrl_l
    bindkey '^l' ctrl_l

Alternatively, you can just add map ctrl+l clear_terminal to_cursor_scroll active to kitty.conf which
works with no changes to the shell rc files, but only clears up to the prompt, it does not clear any text at the prompt itself.

actions.name: reset_window_sizes
actions.short: Reset window sizes undoing any dynamic resizing of windows

actions.name: resize_window
actions.short: Resize the active window by the specified amount
actions.doc: Resize the specified windows in the current layout. Note that not all layouts can resize all windows in all directions.

actions.name: save_as_session
actions.short: Save the current kitty state as a session file

actions.name: scroll_end
actions.short: Scroll to the bottom of the scrollback buffer when in main screen

actions.name: scroll_home
actions.short: Scroll to the top of the scrollback buffer when in main screen

actions.name: scroll_line_down
actions.short: Scroll down by one line when in main screen. To scroll by different amounts, you can map the remote_control scroll-window action.

actions.name: scroll_line_up
actions.short: Scroll up by one line when in main screen. To scroll by different amounts, you can map the remote_control scroll-window action.

actions.name: scroll_page_down
actions.short: Scroll down by one page when in main screen. To scroll by different amounts, you can map the remote_control scroll-window action.

actions.name: scroll_page_up
actions.short: Scroll up by one page when in main screen. To scroll by different amounts, you can map the remote_control scroll-window action.

actions.name: scroll_prompt_to_bottom
actions.short: Scroll prompt to the bottom of the screen, filling in extra lines from the scrollback buffer, when in main screen

actions.name: scroll_prompt_to_top
actions.short: Scroll prompt to the top of the screen, filling screen with empty lines, when in main screen. To avoid putting the lines above the prompt into the scrollback use scroll_prompt_to_top y

actions.name: scroll_to_mark
actions.short: Scroll to the next or previous mark of the specified type

actions.name: scroll_to_next_prompt
actions.short: Scroll to next shell prompt

actions.name: scroll_to_previous_prompt
actions.short: Scroll to previous shell prompt
actions.doc:
Use a parameter of 0 for scroll_to_prompt to scroll to the last
jumped to or the last clicked position. Requires shell integration to work.

actions.name: scroll_to_prompt
actions.short: Scroll to the previous/next shell command prompt
actions.doc:
Allows easy jumping from one command to the next. Requires working
shell_integration. Takes two optional numbers as arguments:

The first is the number of prompts to jump; negative values jump up and
positive values jump down. A value of zero will jump to the last prompt
visited by this action. Defaults to -1

The second is the number of lines to show above the prompt that was
jumped to. This is somewhat like `less`'s `--jump-target` option or
vim's `scrolloff` setting. Defaults to 0.

For example:

    map ctrl+p scroll_to_prompt -1 3  # jump to previous, showing 3 lines prior
    map ctrl+n scroll_to_prompt 1     # jump to next
    map ctrl+o scroll_to_prompt 0     # jump to last visited

actions.name: search_scrollback
actions.short: Search scrollback in a pager like less. If there is selected text, it is automatically searched for.
actions.doc:
Note that this assumes that pressing the / key triggers search mode in the page configured as the
scrollback pager.

actions.name: second_window
actions.short: Focus the second window

actions.name: select_tab
actions.short: Interactively select a tab to switch to

actions.name: send_key
actions.short: Send the specified keys to the active window.
actions.doc:
Note that the key will be sent only if the current keyboard mode of the program running in the terminal supports it.
Both key press and key release are sent. First presses for all specified keys and then releases in reverse order.
To send a pattern of press and release for multiple keys use the combine action. For example:

    map f1 send_key ctrl+x alt+y
    map f1 combine : send_key ctrl+x : send_key alt+y

actions.name: send_text
actions.short: Send the specified text to the active window
actions.doc:
You can tell kitty to send arbitrary (UTF-8) encoded text to the client program
when pressing specified shortcut keys. For example:

    map ctrl+alt+a send_text all Special text

This will send "Special text" when you press the Ctrl+Alt+A key
combination. The text to be sent decodes ANSI C escapes
so you can use escapes like \\e to send control codes or \\u21fb to send
Unicode characters (or you can just input the Unicode characters directly as
UTF-8 text). You can use kitten show-key to get the key escape
codes you want to emulate.

The first argument to send_text is the keyboard modes in which to
activate the shortcut. The possible values are normal,
application, kitty or a comma separated combination of them.
The modes normal and application refer to the DECCKM
cursor key mode for terminals, and kitty refers to the kitty extended
keyboard protocol. The special value all means all of them.

Some more examples:

    # Output a word and move the cursor to the start of the line (like typing and pressing Home)
    map ctrl+alt+a send_text normal Word\e[H
    map ctrl+alt+a send_text application Word\eOH
    # Run a command at a shell prompt (like typing the command and pressing Enter)
    map ctrl+alt+a send_text normal,application some command with arguments\r

actions.name: set_background_opacity
actions.short: Set the background opacity for the active OS Window
actions.doc:
For example:

    map f1 set_background_opacity +0.1
    map f2 set_background_opacity -0.1
    map f3 set_background_opacity 0.5

actions.name: set_colors
actions.short: Change colors in the specified windows
actions.doc:
For details, see at-set-colors. For example:

    map f5 set_colors --configured /path/to/some/config/file/colors.conf

actions.name: set_tab_title
actions.short: Change the title of the active tab interactively, by typing in the new title.
actions.doc:
If you specify an argument to this action then that is used as the title instead of asking for it.
Use the empty string ("") to reset the title to default. Use a space (" ") to indicate that the
prompt should not be pre-filled. For example:

    # interactive usage
    map f1 set_tab_title
    # set a specific title
    map f2 set_tab_title some title
    # reset to default
    map f3 set_tab_title ""
    # interactive usage without prefilled prompt
    map f3 set_tab_title " "

actions.name: set_window_title
actions.short: Change the title of the active window interactively, by typing in the new title.
actions.doc:
If you specify an argument to this action then that is used as the title instead of asking for it.
Use the empty string ("") to reset the title to default. Use a space (" ") to indicate that the
prompt should not be pre-filled. For example:

    # interactive usage
    map f1 set_window_title
    # set a specific title
    map f2 set_window_title some title
    # reset to default
    map f3 set_window_title ""
    # interactive usage without prefilled prompt
    map f3 set_window_title " "

actions.name: seventh_window
actions.short: Focus the seventh window

actions.name: show_error
actions.short: Show an error message with the specified title and text

actions.name: show_first_command_output_on_screen
actions.short: Show output from the first shell command on screen in a pager like less
actions.doc: Requires shell_integration to work

actions.name: show_kitty_doc
actions.short: Display the specified kitty documentation, preferring a local copy, if found.
actions.doc:
For example:

    # show the config docs
    map f1 show_kitty_doc conf
    # show the ssh kitten docs
    map f1 show_kitty_doc kittens/ssh

actions.name: show_kitty_env_vars
actions.short: Show the environment variables that the kitty process sees

actions.name: show_last_command_output
actions.short: Show output from the last shell command in a pager like less
actions.doc: Requires shell_integration to work

actions.name: show_last_non_empty_command_output
actions.short: Show the last non-empty output from a shell command in a pager like less
actions.doc: Requires shell_integration to work

actions.name: show_last_visited_command_output
actions.short: Show the first command output below the last scrolled position via scroll_to_prompt
actions.doc:
or the last mouse clicked command output in a pager like less

Requires shell_integration to work

actions.name: show_scrollback
actions.short: Show scrollback in a pager like less

actions.name: signal_child
actions.short: Send the specified SIGNAL to the foreground process in the active window
actions.doc:
For example:

    map f1 signal_child SIGTERM

actions.name: simulate_color_scheme_preference_change
actions.short: Simulate a change in OS color scheme preference

actions.name: sixth_window
actions.short: Focus the sixth window

actions.name: sleep
actions.short: Sleep for the specified time period. Suffix can be s for seconds, m, for minutes, h for hours and d for days. The time can be fractional.

actions.name: start_resizing_window
actions.short: Resize the active window interactively
actions.doc: Resize the specified windows in the current layout. Note that not all layouts can resize all windows in all directions.

actions.name: swap_with_window
actions.short: Swap the current window with another window in the current tab, selected visually

actions.name: tenth_window
actions.short: Focus the tenth window

actions.name: third_window
actions.short: Focus the third window

actions.name: toggle_fullscreen
actions.short: Toggle the fullscreen status of the active OS Window

actions.name: toggle_layout
actions.short: Toggle the named layout
actions.doc:
Switches to the named layout if another layout is current, otherwise
switches to the last used layout. Useful to "zoom" a window temporarily
by switching to the stack layout. See also scrollback_fill_enlarged_window
if you would like content from the scrollback buffer to scroll down into the
zoomed window. For example:

    map f1 toggle_layout stack

actions.name: toggle_macos_secure_keyboard_entry
actions.short: Toggle macOS secure keyboard entry

actions.name: toggle_marker
actions.short: Toggle the current marker on/off

actions.name: toggle_maximized
actions.short: Toggle the maximized status of the active OS Window

actions.name: toggle_tab
actions.short: Toggle to the tab matching the specified expression
actions.doc:
Switches to the matching tab if another tab is current, otherwise
switches to the last used tab. Useful to easily switch to and back from a
tab using a single shortcut. Note that toggling works only between
tabs in the same OS window. See search_syntax for details
on the match expression. For example:

    map f1 toggle_tab title:mytab

actions.name: ungrab_keyboard
actions.short: Ungrab the keyboard if it was previously grabbed

directives.name: map
directives.doc:
Keys are identified simply by their lowercase Unicode characters. For example:
a for the A key, [ for the left square bracket key, etc.
For functional keys, such as Enter or Escape, the names are present
at Functional key definitions. For modifier keys, the names
are ctrl (control, ⌃), shift (⇧), alt
(opt, option, ⌥), super (cmd, command,
⌘).

Simple shortcut mapping is done with the map directive. For full details
on advanced mapping including modal and per application maps, see mapping.
Some quick examples to illustrate common tasks:

    # unmap a keyboard shortcut, passing it to the program running in kitty
    map kitty_mod+space
    # completely ignore a keyboard event
    map ctrl+alt+f1 discard_event
    # combine multiple actions
    map kitty_mod+e combine : new_window : next_layout
    # multi-key shortcuts
    map ctrl+x>ctrl+y>z action

The full list of actions that can be mapped to key presses is available
here.

directives.name: mouse_map
directives.doc:
Mouse buttons can be mapped to perform arbitrary actions. The syntax is:



    mouse_map button-name event-type modes action

Where button-name is one of left, middle, right,
b1 ... b8 with added keyboard modifiers. For example:
ctrl+shift+left refers to holding the Ctrl+Shift keys while
clicking with the left mouse button. The value b1 ... b8 can be
used to refer to up to eight buttons on a mouse.

event-type is one of press, release,
doublepress, triplepress, click, doubleclick.
modes indicates whether the action is performed when the mouse is
grabbed by the program running in the terminal, or not. The values are
grabbed or ungrabbed or a comma separated combination of them.
grabbed refers to when the program running in the terminal has requested
mouse events. Note that the click and double click events have a delay of
click_interval to disambiguate from double and triple presses.

You can run kitty with the kitty --debug-input command line option
to see mouse events. See the builtin actions below to get a sense of what is
possible.

If you want to unmap a button, map it to nothing. For example, to disable
opening of URLs with a plain click:

    mouse_map left click ungrabbed

See all the mappable actions including mouse actions here.

Note:
    Once a selection is started, releasing the button that started it will
    automatically end it and no release event will be dispatched.
